The benefits of Check 'em Tuesday

13/03/2014

The partnership of Page 3 and Coppafeel! has come under heavy criticism, but anything which raises awareness of the dangers of breast cancer should be welcomed with open arms

Image by

By undefined undefined

Page 3: the phrase instantly conjures up the image of a glamorous, lingerie-clad woman posing in The Sun newspaper. Though this is already a topic of fierce debate, The Sun has made headlines again this week for its decision to link its infamous feature with the breast cancer charity, CoppaFeel! March 4th marked the beginning of the "Check 'em Tuesday" campaign, using Page 3 models to encourage women to check their breasts for any abnormalities or changes. With three pages of the paper and a leading article dedicated to the new scheme, the Sun plans to make this a weekly feature. The Sun's editor, David Dinsdale has stated: "I'm really proud to be a part of this and to be joining up with Coppafeel! We thought we could do some real good with Page 3." The founders of the charity seem equally delighted with the collaboration. Kris Hallenga, herself diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009, declared that Page 3 is a "brilliant platform to get across a life-saving message. They are the most famous boobs in Britain". While the fame of Page 3 cannot be questioned, the insensitive nature of the campaign has come under heavy criticism. On Change.org, the online petitioning forum, Jessica Dean has launched an appeal to force The Sun newspaper to "apologise for the crass and insensitive Page 3 vs Cancer front page" and to "donate profits from that day to Breast Cancer charities". The campaigners also want the newspaper to "run a front cover with a true to life Breast Cancer Care image". Although this suggestion is unquestionably more moral than the current version, it would not work. The entire concept of Page 3, and the reason for its lasting popularity, is its promotion of scantily clad, physically appealing young women. Though the recommended image of an older, less-conventionally attractive, possibly scarred woman would probably be a more representative picture of breast cancer than a glamour model, it would not fit in with the aims and aesthetic of the paper. Thus, it would not happen. Others have questioned the seemingly charitable attitude of The Sun staff: online responses have blasted the initiative as "transparent" and a "cynical exercise in PR". Though this may have some value, it is the effects of the joint campaign, rather than the motives behind it, that should be considered. I doubt that Page 3 will sell more copies for promoting breast cancer awareness, but it has directed media and public attention to the charity and its cause. A final issue is that the readership of Page 3 is traditionally male, suggesting that it is of limited use to promote a breast cancer awareness campaign, which must, essentially, be aimed at women. Though few women may read Page 3 regularly, the general media coverage of the campaign, not to mention the public backlash, has only raised awareness further. I doubt that there are many women who have not heard, through some way or other, that Page 3 and Coppafeel! have united. Page 3's enduring popularity means it is likely to remain. Whatever your opinion of the feature, it might as well be put to some good use. In my opinion, anything that raises awareness of breast cancer, or indeed, any form of cancer, can only be a good thing.
